subSection.paragraph: Review

paragraph.docTitle: Secondary metabolites of seagrasses ( Alismatales and Potamogetonales ; Alismatidae ): Chemical diversity, bioactivity, and ecological function

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Institute of Pharmacy, Department of Pharmacognosy, University of Innsbruck, CCB, Innrain 80-82, Innsbruck, Austria

paragraph.emphasis: A R T I C L E I N F o

subSection.paragraph: Received 3 July 2015
Received in revised form 30 December 2015 Accepted 7 February 2016

Available online
12 February 2016
Chemosystematics
Marine higher plants

paragraph.emphasis: A B S T R A C T

subSection.paragraph:
Seagrasses are the only higher plants living in fully marine environments; they play a significant role in coastal ecosystems. Seagrasses inhabit the coastal shelves of all continents except Antarctica and can grow in depths of up to
90 m .
Because of their eminent ecological importance, innumerous studies have been dedicated to seagrasses and their ecology. However, the phytochemistry has not been equally well investigated yet and many of the existing studies in chemical ecology are only investigating the chemistry at the level of compound classes, e.g. phenolics, and not at the level of chemically defined metabolites. In the present review, the existing literature on secondary metabolites of seagrasses, their known source seagrasses, their bioactivity, and ecological function are compiled and critically assessed. Moreover, research gaps are highlighted and avenues for future research are discussed. Currently, a total of 154 chemically defined natural products have been reported from the about 70 seagrass species known worldwide. Compounds reported include simple phenols derivatives (four compounds), phenylmethane derivatives (14 compounds), phenylethane derivatives (four compounds), phenylpropane derivatives including their esters and dimers (20 compounds), chalkones (four compounds), ssavonoids including catechins (57 compounds), phenylheptanoids (four compounds), one monoterpene derivative, one sesquiterpene, diterpenoids (13 compounds), steroids (31 compounds), and one alkaloid. Most of the existing bioactivity studies of seagrass metabolites and extracts have been directed to potential cytotoxic, antimicrobial, or antimacrofouling activity. Antimicrobial studies have been performed towards panels of both human pathogens and ecologically relevant pathogens. In the antimacrofouling studies, investigations of the potential of zosteric acid from the genus
Zostera
are the most numerous and have yielded so far the most interesting results. Studies on the chemical ecology of seagrasses often have been focused on variation in phenolic compounds and include but are not limited to studies on variation due to abiotic factors, seasonal variation, variation in response to grazing by fish or sea urchins, or following microbial attack.

4. Bioactivities reported from extracts of and pure compounds isolated from seagrasses.............................................. 20
4.6. Antifeedant activity on insects and cytotoxicity towards insect cells....................................................... 21

5.5. Seagrasses as a food source promoting biological invasions.............................................................. 24
5.7. Chemical reactions of seagrasses to microbial infections................................................................. 24

Seagrasses are the only higher plants exclusively living in marine habitats ( den Hartog and Kuo, 2006 ). Currently, seagrasses are assigned to four different families Cymodoceaceae , Hydrocharitaceae , Posidoniaceae , and Zosteraceae ( den Hartog and Kuo, 2006 ; Les and Tippery, 2013 ). According to the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group III System, all four families belong to the monocot order
Alimatales ( Bremer et al., 2009 )
; while Les and Tippery (2013) preferred to treat the same clade as a subclass, Alismatidae. This results in the families of seagrasses to be divided into two different orders: Alismatales , containing seagrasses in the Hydrocharitaceae family and Potamogetonales , containing seagrasses in the Cymodoceaceae , Posidoniaceae , and Zosteraceae families ( Les and Tippery, 2013 ). Cymodoceaceae are exclusively marine organisms and encompass a total of about fifteen species in five genera,
Amphibolis
,
Cymodocea
,
Halodule
,
Syringodium
, and
Thalassodendron
( Mabberley, 2008 ; Duarte et al., 2012 ; Browne et al., 2013 ). Recently, the genus
Ruppia
which mainly inhabits brackish waters was also transferred to the Cymodoceaceae family ( Les and Tippery, 2013 ). Though species of
Ruppia
are not regarded to be seagrasses in the strict sense by most authors, they are also covered here because of their phylogenetic position ( Les and Tippery, 2013 ) and because of their ecological vicinity to ‘‘real” seagrasses.
Ruppia
primarily inhabits brackish waters and one not yet formally described species of
Ruppia
is regarded to be a real seagrass, i.e. exclusively living in fully marine habitats ( den Hartog and Kuo, 2006 ).

The monogeneric family Posidoniaceae encompasses the Mediterranean
Posidonia oceanica
and eight additional seagrass species living off the coasts of Southern Australia . Zosteraceae are also exclusively marine organisms and contain 22 species in three genera,
Heterozostera
[recently included in
Zostera ( Les and Tippery, 2013 )
,
Phyllospadix
, and
Zostera ( Mabberley, 2008 )
]. Likewise, Hydrocharitaceae , which mainly comprise genera restricted to freshwater habitats encompass three exclusively marine genera, the monotypic
Enhalus
,
Halophila
with ten, and
Thalassia
with two species ( Mabberley, 2008 ).

Seagrasses are no phylogenetic link between marine algae and land living higher plants but are derived from land plants which have secondarily recolonized marine habitats, similar to dolphins, manatees, and whales in mammals ( Ackerman, 2006 ). Therefore, seagrasses share most features of their primary and secondary metabolism with their relatives from the Alismatales s.l. order which live on land or in freshwater habitats.

In the present review, building on a previous review on secondary metabolites from
Posidonia oceanica ( Heglmeier and Zidorn, 2010 )
and the rather superficial review on all genera of seagrasses by Subhashini et al. (2013) , the secondary metabolite profile of all currently known genera of seagrasses (see above) are reviewed. Literature was searched using the Google Scholar, ISI Web of Knowledge, and Sci Finder databases. The nomenclature of the species which have been studied has been adapted to the standard usage given in the International Plant Names Index IPNI (www.ipni.org). In order to ease reading of the text, author citations have uniformly omitted from the ssowing text. However, in order to have easy access to these data, the respective author citations for all species mentioned in the text are given in Table S1 of the supplementary material (which also gives a quick overview from which source species the 154 numbered defined chemical compounds mentioned below have been reported from). Deviating from IPNI nomenclature,
Zostera noltii
, a species named in honor of a certain Professor Nolte from Kiel, is named
Z. noltii
as in Hornemann’s (1832) original description and not
Z. noltei
as in IPNI.

Seagrass metabolites were also compendiously covered by Larkum et al. (2006a) in the magnificent volume on seagrasses by Larkum et al. (2006b) . These authors emphasized the occurrence of inositol derivatives in seagrasses but based on prior work were not able to provide a rationale for this accumulation though some role in osmoregulation seems plausible. Other compound classes which were briessy mentioned by Larkum et al. (2006a) are sugars, amino acids, alkanes, lipids, and phenolics.

Seagrasses like other photosynthetic higher plants have a lower light limit below which photosynthesis rates do not exceed respiration rates and therefore photosynthesis based plant life is not possible anymore. Under optimal water conditions (optimal water transparency and sufficiently high water temperatures), this point is reached between 50 and 60 m water depths in Europe ( Borum and Greve, 2004 ) and 90 m water depths in the tropics ( Duarte, 1991 ). Indeed under optimal conditions, seagrass ecosystems range among the most productive ecosystems with regards to net primary production rates ( Mateo et al., 2006 ).

Seagrasses, in contrast to algae, possess lignin as a cell wall strengthening polymer, a feature retained from their land dwelling ancestors ( Klap et al., 2000 ). Also the profile of fatty acids from lipids of seagrasses such as
Posidonia oceanica
differs from sympatric species of algae and thus could possibly enable identification of
Posidonia
residues in marine sediments (Viso et al., 1993). Hammami et al. (2013) confirmed the occurrence of palmitic, palmitoleic, oleic, and linoleic acid in
P. oceanica
.

A hydrolysate of
Posidonia australis
fibers yielded the relatively rare monosaccharide D-(+)-apiose ( Bell et al., 1954 ). The fatty acid distribution in seven seagrass species from Queensland / Australia was analyzed by Gillan et al. (1984) and the results were analyzed by cluster analysis. Congeneric taxa were in all cases more similar to each other than taxa from different genera. Unfortunately, the authors analyzed one sample per taxon only. In total 30 different fatty acids with chain lengths ranging from C 12 to C 28 and with zero to three double bonds were identified and quantified in this study ( Gillan et al., 1984 ).

In the following paragraphs the literature on seagrass secondary metabolites has been compiled in alphabetic order of the source species, irrespective of the family the taxa are currently assigned to. In order to give a first overview about each reviewed genus, the section titles include the name of the reviewed genus and in brackets the number of species, the family (according to Les and Tippery, 2013 ), and the geographic range. Compound structures ordered by compound class are depicted in Figs. 1–19 .

Natural products isolated from fungi derived from seagrasses have not been covered here (e.g. studied by Kasai et al., 2005 ; Arunpanichlert et al., 2011 ; Smetanina et al., 2011 ). Preliminary studies for the occurrence of compound classes using rather historic methodology such as the one of Athiperumalsami et al. (2008) who studied the (presumed) occurrence and absence of alkaloids, anthraquinones, catechins, coumarins, ssavonoids, phenols, quinones, saponins, tannins, and some primary metabolites in the Indian seagrasses
Cymodocea serrulata
,
Halodule pinifolia
, and
Syringodium isoetifolium
using the methodology described by Harborne (1973) have also not been further considered. A complete overview about all investigated species and the compounds reported for each species can be found in the Supplementary material in Table S1.

The distributions of sterols and fatty acids (see above) in seven seagrass species from Queensland / Australia were analyzed by Gillan et al. (1984) and the results were analyzed by cluster analysis. Probably due to the fact that only five sterols, cholesterol 134 , campesterol 137 , sitosterol 142 , isofucosterol 144 , and stigmasterol 145 , but 30 fatty acids, were quantified, quantification data from fatty acids led to a chemosystematically more meaningful clustering of the investigated taxa. Interestingly, all five sterols were – though of course in different quantities ― detected in all seven investigated species:
C. serrulata
,
E. acoroides
,
Halodule uninervis
,
Halophila ovalis
,
Halophila ovata
,
Halophila spinulosa
, and
T. hemprichii
.

heading.emphasis: 3.2. Amphibolis (2, Cymodoceaceae, western and southern coast of Australia )

subSubSection.paragraph:
In
A. antarctica
collected in Shark Bay, Western Australia , diterpene hydrocarbons 120–122 were detected ( Dunlop, 1985 ).

heading.emphasis: 3.3. Cymodocea (4, Cymodoceaceae, West African, Canary Islands , and Mediterranean coasts)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Investigations of
Cymodocea nodosa
collected off the coast of Greece yielded phenylheptanoids 104–107 ( Kontiza et al., 2005 , 2008 ) as well as ketosteroids 148–151 ( Kontiza et al., 2006 ). Moreover, Kontiza et al. (2008) found the meroterpenoid 108 and the brominated briarane diterpene
119 in
Cymodocea nodosa
.

Grignon-Dubois and Rezzonico (2013) found high amounts of cichoric acid
36 in
detrital and fresh specimens of
Cymodocea nodosa
( Cymodoceaceae ) from the Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea. Leaves contained much higher amounts of 36 than rhizomes, 8.13 to 27.44 mg/g and 0.31–3.70 mg/g dry plant material, respectively.

heading.emphasis: 3.4. Enhalus (1, Hydrocharitaceae, coasts from Indomalaya to the West Pacific)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Qi et al. (2008) isolated besides 1-hexocosanol (here not numbered and depicted because considered to be a primary metabolite), p -hydroxybenzaldehyde 5 , ssavonoids apigenin 47 , luteolin 57 , luteolin 4
0
-glucuronide 60 , and luteolin 3
0
-glucuronide 61 , and sterols 130 , 143 , 146 , 151 , and 153 , from an ethanol extract of
E. acoroides
collected off the coast of Hainan , Southern China .

To the best of our knowledge there are no reports on secondary metabolites from species of the genus
Halodule
apart from the comparative studies from Zapata and McMillan (1979) and Gillan et al. (1984) mentioned in Section 3.1.

heading.emphasis: 3.6. Halophila (10, Hydrocharitaceae, tropical coasts of the West
Indies, the Indian and Pacific Oceans)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Harborne and Williams (1976) reported partially characterized caffeoylquinic acid sulfates from
Halophila baillonis
and
H. engelmannii
. In
H. baillonis
the authors moreover detected a partially characterized ssavone O -sulfate derivative.

In an early chemosystematic paper, McMillan (1983) correlated the occurrence of sulfated ssavonoids (unfortunately not further characterized) and the leaf morphology (small-leaved versus large-leaved) in taxa from the
H. ovalis – H. minor
group from the Pacific Islands and Australia . The author reported a perfect correlation of chemical and morphological characters with sulfated ssavonoids only and consistently occurring in the large-leaved populations investigated.

Meng et al. (2008) reported on ssavonoids of
Halophila johnsonii
. Compounds 47 , 57 , 79 , 80 , 81 , 82 , 87 , 88 , 89 , 90 , 93 , and 94 were recorded in both rhizomes and leaves while the occurrence of 86 and 78 was restricted to the rhizomes. The identity of a fifteenth compound reported by these authors remains unclear because there is a mismatch between the indicated figure and the name (myricetin), we therefore omit this record.

Gaul et al. (2011)
identified 2,3,4,5-tetrabromo-1-methylpyrrole
154 in
H. ovalis
collected off the coast of Queensland , Australia . Though the authors assumed that this compound was not synthesized by the seagrass itself but taken up from the environment, they suspect a natural (marine bacteria) rather than an industrial source for this compound.

Halophila stipulacea
yielded two structurally unique macrocyclic diterpene glycoside methylglucaryl derivatives 117 and 118 ( Gavagnin et al., 2007 ; Carbone et al., 2008 ). Moreover, Mollo et al. (2008) mentioned the ssavonoids apigenin 47 , genkwanin 53 , and chrysoeriol 67 from this species. Bitam et al. (2010) reported the ssavonoids 48 , 50 , 52 , 54 , 55 , 68 , and 70 from
H. stipulacea
collected off the coast of Greece . Mollo et al. (2015) in more detail discussed the chemistry of the species pair composed of the seagrass
H. stipulacea
and the mollusk
Syphonota geographica
as an example of interdependent bioinvasions in their position paper.

This formerly monotypic genus has recently been merged with
Zostera ( Les and Tippery, 2013 )
. Publications dealing with
Z. tasmanica
(synonym:
H. tasmanica
) would therefore have been dealt with under
Zostera
(to the best of our knowledge, they do not exist, except for a comparative paper already discussed in Section 3.1).

heading.emphasis: 3.8. Lepilaena (4, Potamogetonaceae/Zannichelliaceae, Australia and New Zealand )

subSubSection.paragraph:
The genus
Lepilaena
is mainly distributed in freshwater habitats of Australia and New Zealand . Only
Lepilaena marina
has the ecological characteristics of a seagrass ( den Hartog and Kuo, 2006 ; Mabberley, 2008 ). So far no studies on secondary metabolites of any member of the genus
Lepilaena
seem to have been performed.

heading.emphasis: 3.9. Phyllospadix (5, Zosteraceae, coasts of Japan and Western North

subSubSection.paragraph:
Takagi et al. (1980) reported besides common ssavonoids luteolin 57 and hispidulin 83 the unusual ssavonoid-alkaloid phyllospadin 95 from
Phyllospadix iwatensis
collected off the coast of Japan . Takagi et al. (1979) described ssavonoids 56 , 57 , 65 , 66 , 83 , 84 , 85 , 91 , and 92 from
Phyllospadix japonicus
(named
Phyllospadix japonica
in this paper) collected off the coast of Japan .

heading.emphasis: 3.10. Posidonia (9, Posidoniaceae, coasts of the Mediterranean and Australia )

subSubSection.paragraph:
Secondary metabolites of
P. oceanica
and problems related to some older studies have been reviewed recently ( Heglmeier and Zidorn, 2010 ) and secondary metabolites known from this species encompassed until then compounds 1–10 , 12–18 , 20–22 , 24–25 , 28–31 , 36 , 43–44 , 96–97 , 100–101 , 123–129 , 134–142 , 144–145 .

In order to avoid a mere replication of the previous review ( Heglmeier and Zidorn, 2010 ), the details of the isolation and identification of compounds 1–10 , 12–18 , 20–22 , 24–25 , 28–31 , 36 , 43–44 , 96–97 , 100–101 , 123–129 , 134–142 ,
144– 145
in
P. oceanica
are not repeated here. Instead solely the source publications for each compound are indicated: Phenol 1 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), phloroglucinol 2 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), pyrocatechol 3 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), pyrogallol 4 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998), 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde 5 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), 3,4-dihydroxybenzaldehyde 6 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), vanillin 7 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ; Haznedaroglu and Zeybek, 2007 , syringa aldehyde 8 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), benzoic acid 9 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), p -hydroxybenzoic acid 10 (Cariello et al., 1979; Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ; Dumay et al., 2004 ), p -anisic acid 12 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), protocatechuic acid 13 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), vanillic acid 14 (Cariello et al., 1979; Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), vanillic acid derivative 15 (Cariello et al., 1979), gallic acid 16 ( Agostini et al., 1998 ), syringic acid 17 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), gentisic acid 18 ( Haznedaroglu and Zeybek, 2007 ), piceol 20 ( Agostini et al., 1998 ), acetovanillone 21 ( Agostini et al., 1998 ), acetosyringone 22 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), cinnamic acid 24 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ; Dumay et al., 2004 ; Haznedaroglu and Zeybek, 2007 ), coumaric acid 25 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ; Dumay et al., 2004 ; Haznedaroglu and Zeybek, 2007 ), caffeic acid 28 ( Agostini et al., 1998 ; Dumay et al., 2004 ; Haznedaroglu and Zeybek, 2007 ), ferulic acid 29 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ; Dumay et al., 2004 ; Haznedaroglu and Zeybek, 2007 ), sinapic acid 30 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ; Agostini et al., 1998 ), chlorogenic acid 31 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ), cichoric acid 36 (Cariello and Zanetti, 1979; Cariello et al., 1979; Haznedaroglu and Zeybek, 2007 ), phloretin 43 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ), phloridzin 44 ( Cuny et al., 1995 ), kaempferol 96 ( Cannac et al., 2006 , 2007 ), quercetin 97 ( Cannac et al., 2006 , 2007 ), isorhamnetin 100 ( Cannac et al., 2006 , 2007 ), myricetin 101 ( Cannac et al., 2006 , 2007 ), 5OE- cholestan-3-ol 123 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), 5OE- cholest-22 E -en-3-ol 124 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), 5OE- campestanol 125 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), 5OEergostanol 126 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), 5OE-24-methylcholest-24(28)- en-3-ol 127 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), 5OE- β- sitostanol 128 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), 5OE- isofucostanol 129 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), cholesterol 134 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), desmosterol 135 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), cholesta-5,22-diene-3β- ol 136 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), campesterol 137 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), dihydrobrassicasterol 138 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), epibrassicasterol 139 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), brassicasterol 140 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), 24-methylenecholesterol 141 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), β- sitosterol 142 ( Sica et al., 1984 ), isofucosterol 144 , ( Sica et al., 1984 ), and stigmasterol 145 ( Sica et al., 1984 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 14. 5OE- Steroids without double bonds and epidioxy-groups in the ring system.
Fig. 15. 5OE- Steroids with a double bond in position 6, 8 or 8(14).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Since the publication of the review on
P. oceanica
secondary metabolites ( Heglmeier and Zidorn, 2010 ), Bitam et al. (2012) reported four neolignans 39–42 from
P. oceanica
collected in the Gulf of Naples, Italy . Moreover, Hammami et al. (2013) discovered the new sesquiterpene alcohol posidozinol 109 from plants collected off the coast of Tunisia . Additionally, these authors confirmed the occurrence of β- sitosterol
142 in
P. oceanica
. Harborne and Williams (1976) had reported on the occurrence of partially sulfated caffeoyl quinic acid derivatives in
P. oceanica
and moreover indicated the presence of not further specified procyanidins in a sample of this taxon collected off the coast of Malta .

Most recently, Grignon-Dubois and Rezzonico (2015) described cichoric acid 36 , caftaric acid 35 together with mono- and di- coumaric 33 , 34 and ferulic tartaric acid derivatives 37 , 38 from
P. oceanica
. Cichoric acid 36 was unambiguously identified as the major phenolic compound, regardless of the sample or collection site and caftaric acid 35 , the second most abundant phenolic in the analyzed samples, was reported for the first time from
Posidonia
. Moreover, the authors highlighted the pronounced effects of extract handling and of choosing adequate criteria to identify natural compounds in extracts, because their results contrasted sharply with previous studies of
P. oceanica
. Indeed, ferulic acid 29 was found as a trace compound only and the authors failed to detect any traces of acetosyringone 22 .

Additionally, these authors reported traces of rutin 99 , isorhamnetin 3- O -glucoside, and isorhamnetin 3- O -rutinoside detected by HPLC (addition in proofs, thus without depiction of isorhamnetin 3- O -glucoside and isorhamnetin 3- O -rutinoside and without compound numbers for these compounds, which have not been reported from any other seagrass source yet).

heading.emphasis: 3.11. Ruppia (7, Cymodoceaceae, salt, alkaline, and brackish waters, in temperate to subtropical zones)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Only one, so far not formally described species of
Ruppia
,
Ruppia aff. tuberosa ( den Hartog and Kuo, 2006 )
, is considered to be a true seagrass in the ecological sense. However, other species of
Ruppia
inhabit brackish waters, including nearly fully saline environments. Therefore, records on the phytochemistry of
Ruppia
are covered here. Harborne and Williams (1976) reported on the occurrence of partially characterized sulfated caffeoyl quinic acid derivatives in
Ruppia maritima
collected off the coast of Wales . Leaves of
R. maritima
collected in brackish waters of the Volturno river mouth near Naples/ Italy yielded seven diterpenes 110–116 ( DellaGreca et al., 2000 ). DellaGreca et al. (2001) reported ten sterols from
R. maritima
. Besides known compounds 133 , 137 , 142 , 145 , 147 , 149 , 152 , and 153 , two new trihydroxysterols, ( 24R )- ergosta-8(14),22diene-3β,6β,7OE- triol 131 and ( 24R )-ergosta-8,22- diene-3β,6β,7OE- triol 132 were isolated.

heading.emphasis: 3.12. Syringodium (2, Cymodoceaceae, Indian and Western Pacific Oceans and Caribbean)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Harborne and Williams (1976) reported on the occurrence of partially characterized sulfated caffeoyl quinic acid derivatives in
S. filiforme
collected off the coast of Jamaica . Moreover, these authors detected (as in
P. oceanica
) the presence of procyanidins in this taxon. Only the compound class but no defined natural products were detected and therefore no compound number can be assigned here.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 16. Steroids with a double bond in position 5.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Nussier et al. (2010) identified cichoric acid 36 and caftaric acid 35 as the main phenolics in fresh leaves and detritus of leaves from
S. filiforme
. Additionally, traces of tartaric acid derivatives 33–34 and 37–38 and traces of simple phenolic acids 10 , 14 , 24 , and 28 were detected by HPLC-DAD-MS.

heading.emphasis: 3.13. Thalassia (2, Hydrocharitaceae, Caribbean, tropical Indian and Pacific Oceans)

subSubSection.paragraph:
T. hemprichii
collected off the coast of China yielded 10 , 16 , 19 , 23 , 27 , 28 , 36 , 62 , 71 , 73 , and 74 ( Qi et al., 2012 ).
T. hemprichii
collected off the coast of Egypt yielded five phenolics, caffeic acid 28 , rosmarinic acid 32 (though the structure in the original publication shows a similar but different compound), and ssavonoids 75–77 ( Hawas, 2014 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 17. Steroids with a double bond in position 4.

subSubSection.paragraph:
T. testudinum
was found to contain chrysoeriol 7- O -sulfate 69 , using analytical 2D paper chromatography ( Harborne and Williams, 1976 ). The compound was isolated during the same study from
Z. marina
. Moreover, these authors reported on the occurrence of one partially characterized chrysoeriol derivative and partially characterized sulfated caffeoyl quinic acid derivatives.
T. testudinum
collected off the coast of the Bahamas provided the first source of 62 ( Jensen et al., 1998 ).
T. testudinum
collected off the coast of the Bahamas yielded three sulfated ssavonoids 51 , 62 , and 71 ( Rowley et al., 2002 ). Using RP-HPLC, Steele et al. (2005) identified and quantified vanillin 7 , p -hydroxybenzoic acid 10 , 3,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid 13 , and p -coumaric acid
25 in
leaves of
T. testudinum
collected off the coast of Florida. Compound identifications were based on retention times only and the extraction method with 2% acetic acid in methanol/water 1/1 as extraction solvent was rather harsh; therefore, the detected compounds might also represent other compounds with similar polarity or hydrolysis products of more complex genuine natural products.

Nogueiras et al. (2010) confirmed the presence of 10 , 51 , 62 , and
71 in
T. testudinum
. Regalado et al. (2011) studied the apolar compounds of a
T. testudinum
leaf-extract by gas chromatography. A total of 43 compounds (structures not shown) were detected and 1,1-bis-( p -tolyl)-ethane, 4,4’-diisopropylbiphenyl, and an 1,1-bis-( p -tolyl)-ethane isomer were identified as the main compounds.
T. testudinum
leaves collected off the coast of Cuba yielded eleven phenolics ( 5 , 10 , 11 , 47 , 50–51 , 58 , 67 , and 70–72 ), including the new natural product ethyl 4-(sulfoxy)-benzoate 11 ( Regalado et al., 2012 ). However, based on the described isolation procedures, it is likely that the new compound 11 is actually an artefact generated in the course of the extraction (with a 1/1 ethanol/water mixture) and isolation process and not a genuine natural product. Bio-guided fractionation (against
Labyrinthula
protists) resulted in the identification of vanillin 7 , p -hydroxybenzoic acid 10 , 3,4- dihydroxybenzoic acid 13 , and p -coumaric acid 25 as the active principles in leaves of
T. testudinum (Trevathan-Tackett et al., 2015)
.

paragraph.emphasis: 3.14. Thalassodendron (3, Cymodoceaceae, Red Sea, Western Indian Ocean, coast of Eastern Malaysia , NE and SW Australia , and coasts of Southern Africa)

subSubSection.paragraph:
T. ciliatum
collected in the Red Sea off the Egyptian coast yielded caffeic acid 28 , the dihydrochalcones asebotin 45 and 3-hydroxyasebotin 46 , the ssavonoids quercetin 3- O -β- D- xylopyranoside 98 and rutin 99 , and a mixture of (+)-catechin 102 and ( ― )-catechin 103 ( Hamdy et al., 2012 ).

Mohammed et al. (2014) additionally reported the following phenolics from
T. ciliatum
collected in the Red Sea near Hurghada/ Egypt (addition in proofs, thus without depiction and compound numbers for asebogenin 6- O -rutinoside and quercetin 3,7-di- O -glucoside, which have only been reported for this species): chalcones asebotin 45 and asebogenin 6- O -rutinoside (trivial name suggested by the authors: thalassodendrone), the ssavonoid quercetin 3-7- O -diglucoside, and phenolic acids 10 , 13 , and 29 .

heading.emphasis: 3.15. Zostera (9, Zosteraceae, cold to warm coastal waters worldwide but excluding the tropics)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Following Borum and Greve (2004) , we consider
Zostera angustifolia
to be part of
Z. marina
and
Zostera nana
to be a synonym of
Z. noltii
.
Z. marina
collected off the coast of Plymouth , UK , yielded five ssavonoid 7- O -sulfate derivatives 49 , 59 , 63–64 , and 69 ( Harborne and Williams, 1976 ).
Z. noltii
(as
Z. nana
) was found to also contain 59 and
64 in
the same study ( Harborne and Williams, 1976 ). By implication, it might be assumed that the sulfated ssavonoids detected in a sample of
Z. marina
(as
Z. angustifolia
) collected off the coast of Devon were assignable to 59 , 64 , and 69 . Harborne’s (1975) review on ssavonoid sulfates contains neither additional data for the occurrence of these compounds in
Zostera
nor for other seagrass genera. Quackenbush et al. (1986) described an early RP-HPLC method for phenolic acids in
Z. marina
. Based on retention times, the authors detected 10 , 13 , 14 , 16 , 18 , 28 , and
29 in
an extract of
Z. marina
collected off the coast of the US state of Washington . Apart from general concerns on the suitability of HPLC retention times as the sole criterion for compound identification, the presented data (HPLC retention times and their standard deviations for pure compounds and the allegedly same compounds in a
Z. marina
extract), indicate that the presence of the above mentioned should be confirmed in
Z. marina
using more appropriate techniques. Also using HPLC retention times, Vergeer and Develi (1997) identified 16 , 25 , 28 , and
29 in
Z. marina
leaves collected off the coast of Brittany , France . In this study on top of the concerns raised above, the extraction procedure was so harsh that artefact formation seems to be likely. So even if the compounds were indeed present in the analyzed extracts, it remains unclear whether they were genuine natural products or artefacts (or at least partially so, i.e. the natural products could still occur as genuine natural products but not in the amounts implied by the quantification results). Buchsbaum et al. (1990) confirmed the presence of 59 and
63 in
Z. marina
.

Zosteric acid 26 was first discovered by Todd et al. (1993) in
Z. marina
. Due to its interesting antifouling bioactivities (see Sections 4.2 and 4.5 below), even detritus derived from
Zostera
leaves was investigated as a potential source of 26 ( Achamlale et al., 2009 ). In this study, also
Z. noltii
was detected to contain 26 .
Z. marina
collected off the coast of Qingdao, China , yielded rosmarinic acid 32 (Wang et al., 2012). In an interesting study unfortunately limited to only four sampling sites, Grignon-Dubois et al. (2012) investigated regional differences in the contents of 26 , 28 , and
32 in
Z. noltii
. The authors observed huge absolute differences in amounts (potentially related to a different status of defence against potential pathogens but potentially also due to genetic differences) of the quantified phenolic acids while the relative amounts of these compounds varied only marginally (with rosmarinic acid 32 being the most and caffeic acid 28 the least abundant compound).

paragraph.emphasis: 4. Bioactivities reported from extracts of and pure compounds isolated from seagrasses

subSection.paragraph: Bioactivities reported for seagrass extracts and for pure compounds derived from seagrass extracts have been summarized in the following sections by activity. In contrast to activities reported for seagrasses and their extracts and pure compounds, activities reported for extracts and pure compounds derived from fungi associated with seagrasses have not been covered here (e.g. the studies by Supaphon et al., 2013 , 2014 ).

Cymodienol 107 from
Cymodocea nodosa
was demonstrated to have significant in vitro cytotoxicity against two human lung cancer cell lines, while cymodiene 104 from the same source was only moderately active ( Kontiza et al., 2005 ). Ketosteroids 148–151 from
Cymodocea nodosa
showed no in vitro cytotoxicity against these cell lines ( Kontiza et al., 2006 ). Syphonoside 117 from
H. stipulacea
showed no in vitro cytotoxicity up to concentrations of 400 µM but on the contrary inhibited apoptosis in some of the cell lines investigated ( Gavagnin et al., 2007 ). Crude extracts of
T. ciliatum
exhibited cytotoxic activity against selected human cancer cell lines and some activity against hepatitis A and herpes simplex viruses in vitro ( Hamdy et al., 2012 ).

Devi et al. (1997) investigated the activity of extracts from sixteen marine species including seagrasses
Halodule pinifolia
,
Halophila ovalis
, and
S. isoetifolium
against 15 strains of marine fouling bacteria.
H. pinifolia
showed no bioactivity against any of the tested bacteria,
H. pinifolia
showed only weak inhibition (inhibition zone 1 to 2 mm ) of a strain from the Anterobacteriaceae, while
S. isoetifolium
showed weak inhibition of this and four additional strains, a strain each from the genera Alkalegenes , Arthrobacterium ,
Flavobacterium
, and
Pseudomonas
.

Engel et al. (2006) surveyed extracts of tropical Atlantic marine plants against various marine plant pathogens. The panel of test organisms consisted of the pathogenic fungus
Lindra thalassiae
, the saprophytic fungus
Dendryphiella salina
, the saprophytic stramenopiles,
Halophytophthora spinosa
and
Schizochytrium aggregatum
, and the pathogenic bacterium
Pseudoaltermonas bacteriolytica
. Among the marine plant extracts of which were assayed for anti-pathogenic activity were also three seagrass species:
Halodule beaudettei
,
S. filiforme
, and
T. testudinum
. None of the extracts from these species was active against fungi; all were active against stramenopiles. Among the tested extracts,
H. beaudettei
extracts were the most active, inhibiting the growth of
H. spinosa
,
S. aggregatum
, and
P. bacteriolytica
. The extracts from
S. filiforme
were active against
S. aggregatum
, and
P. bacteriolytica
, while the extracts from
T. testudinum
were only active against
H. spinosa
.

Ross et al. (2008) studied the antifungal activities of organic extracts from five seagrass species from Florida ,
H. wrightii
,
Halophila decipiens
,
R. maritima
,
S. filiforme
, and
T. testudinum
, for their antifungal activities. The panel of fungi consisted of species ecologically relevant in the marine and terrestrial environment and encompassed two strains of
D. salina
,
L. thalassiae
, and three species of
Fusarium
. Crude extracts of all tested seagrass species except
S. filiforme
inhibited the growth of at least one fungal strain by 35%. The strains of
D. salina
and one of the three
Fusarium species
studied were not inhibited by any of the crude extracts. In contrast, another
Fusarium species
appeared to be the most susceptible. Broad-spectrum activity against three of the six fungal strains was observed in the extract of
R. maritima
. Extracts from
Halodule wrightii
,
Halophila decipiens
,
R. maritima
, and
T. testudinum
were active against the most susceptible
Fusarium species
, whereas, only extracts from
R. maritima
and
T. testudinum
inhibited the growth of the third tested
Fusarium species.
The pathogen
L. thalassiae
was only inhibited by the extracts from
R. maritima
.

Cymodocea nodosa
metabolites 105 , 106 , 107 , 108 , and 119 were evaluated for their antibacterial activity ( Kontiza et al., 2008 ) and in particular nodosol 108 was found to possess pronounced activity. Kumar et al. (2008) reported about antibacterial activity of extracts of different polarity obtained from
C. serrulata
,
H. ovalis
, and
Zostera capensis
using the agar diffusion test assay. The authors reported the most pronounced activities against the panel of human pathogens consisting of
Bacillus cereus
,
Bacillus subtilis
,
Escherichia coli
,
Micrococcus luteus
,
Salmonella paratyphi
,
Salmonella typhimurium
, and
Staphylococcus aureus
, for the methanol and ethyl acetate extracts of all three investigated species.

Iyapparaj et al. (2014) reported activity against biofilm forming bacteria and anti-micro-algal activity for extracts of
C. serrulata
and
S. isoetifolium
. Qi et al. (2008) reported moderate activity of ssavonoids 57 and 60 and 1-hexaconasol isolated from
E. acoroides
on a panel of test bacteria. Interestingly, the activities of the three assayed compounds were complementary, i.e. each compound had a unique set of bacteria against which it was active. In a study on the activity of extracts of various marine plants (higher and lower), seagrasses
E. acoroides
and
H. minor
showed activity against
Dendryphiella salina , Pseudoaltermonas
bacteriolytica
, and
Schizochytrium aggregatum
, and against
Halophytophthora spinosa
and
S. aggregatum
, respectively ( Puglisi et al., 2007 ).

Yuvaraj et al. (2012) studied extracts of
H. ovalis
for their antibacterial activity against
Acinetobacter baumannii
,
B. cereus
,
E. coli
, and four Vibrio species ,
Vibrio anguillarum
,
Vibrio fischeri
,
Vibrio parahaemolyticus
, and
Vibrio vulnificus
. The most susceptible bacterium was
B. cereus
followed by
A. baumannii
.

P. oceanica
extracts were found to be active against Grampositive and Gram-negative bacteria, dermatophytes, and yeasts ( Bernard and Pesando, 1989 ). Orhan et al. (2006) detected some activity of ethanolic
P. oceanica
extracts against
Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense
and
Leishmania donovani
in an investigation of various Turkish freshwater and marine macrophytes. Moreover, Gokce and Haznedaroglu (2008) reported on antidiabetic, antioxidant, and vasoprotective activities of an aqueous ethanolic (50%) extract of
P. oceanica
leaves. Though these authors did not identify the active principles, they showed that antidiabetic and vasoprotective activities of
P. oceanica
are not primarily related to the antioxidant activity of the extract. Indirectly, based on the spectrum of phenolic compounds known from
Posidonia , Haznedaroglu and Zeybek (2007)
postulated potential anti-HIV, immunostimulant, antitumor, and antioxidant activities of
Posidonia
extracts.

Flavonoids 75–77 from
T. hemprichii
showed antibacterial activity against
B. subtilis
,
E. coli
,
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
, and
Staphylococcus aureus
in an agar plate diffusion assay with 77 being the most active compound ( Hawas, 2014 ).

The ssavonoid 62 isolated from
T. testudinum
proved to be active against both the mycelia and the zoospores of the co-occurring marine fungus
S. aggregatum ( Jensen et al., 1998 )
. Vanillin 7 , p -Hydroxybenzoic acid 10 , 3,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid 13 , and p -coumaric acid 25 from leaves of
T. testudinum
proved to be active against the
Labyrinthula
protists in a dose-dependent manner with 3,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid 13 being the most active compound (Trevathan-Tackett et al., 2015).

Water soluble fractions of methanol and methanol/water 4/1 extracts of
Z. marina
were evaluated for their anti-bacterial and anti-micro-algal activity ( Harrison and Chan, 1980 ). Activity was found against the diatoms
Cylindrotheca fusiformis
,
Nitzschia angularis
,
Nitzschia frustulum
,
Nitzschia longissima
, and
Skeletonema costatum
, the bacterium
Staphylococcus aureus
, and the ssagellate
Platymonas spp.
No attempts were made to identify the compounds causing this activity. In a follow up study ( Harrison, 1982 ) protocatechuic acid 13 , gentisic acid 18 , and caffeic acid 28 were identified as responsible for at least part of the observed activity. In a third study in this series, Harrison and Durance (1985) demonstrated that water-soluble extracts
of Z. marina
inhibited carbon uptake of epiphytic diatoms.

Zosteric acid 26 was first discovered by Todd et al. (1993) in
Z. marina
and proved to have antimicrofouling activity against an undefined species of
Acinetobacter
. Zosteric acid 26 also proved to be an effective antimicrofoulant with dose-dependent effects against both Lake Erie bacteria in general and
Pseudomonas putida
in particular ( Newby et al., 2006 ). Experimentally prepared silicone based coatings containing 26 proved to significantly delay microfouling. In recent years the application of zosteric acid 26 as an antifoulant has gained a lot of attention (a Google Scholar search for the search term ‘zosteric acid fouling’ yielded 190 hits on 07/05/2015 ) and to fully cover all publications dedicated to the antifouling activity of this compound would require a dedicated review of its own.

Vergeer and Develi (1997) showed anti-
Labyrinthula
activity for phenolic acids 16 , 25 , 28 , and 29 from
Z. marina
indicating that these compounds might be part of the natural defence of
Zostera
against this pathogen.

Rosmarinic acid 32 isolated from
Z. marina
showed nematicidal activity against the pine wood nematode
Bursaphelenchus xylophilus
and antibacterial activities against the following species of bacteria associated with the nematode:
Klebsiella sp.
,
Pantoea agglomerans
,
Stenotrophomonas maltophilia
, and
Streptomyces sp.
(Wang et al., 2012). Extracts of both
Z. marina
and
Z. noltii
proved to be algicidal against the dinossagellate
Alexandrium catenella ( Laabir et al., 2013 )
. The authors provided some preliminary scientific evidence to suggest that phenolics might be causing this activity but unfortunately did not identify the active compound(s).

Flavonoids 51 , 62 , and 71 from
T. testudinum
showed in vitro activity against HIV cDNA integrase ( Rowley et al., 2002 ). Zosteric acid 26 from
Z. marina
had moderate anti-Dengue-virus activity and semi-synthetic compounds derived from 26 had potent activity against all four types of Dengue virus ( Rees et al., 2008 ; Kadir et al., 2013 ).

Diterpenes 110–116 from
R. maritima
were tested for their toxicity on the unicellular green alga
Raphidocelis subcapitata
, commonly used as a bioindicator, and compounds 112–113 , and 116 were found to be the most toxic compounds towards the alga ( DellaGreca et al., 2000 ).

Iyapparaj et al. (2014) reported anti-macrofouling activities for extracts of
C. serrulata
and
S. isoetifolium
using a mollusc foot adherence assay (using the limpet
Patella vulgata
as a test organism), an anti-mussel bioassay (using
Perna indica
as a test organism and inhibition of byssal production, inhibition of attachment, and LC 50 as activity criteria), and an anti-crustacean assay (using
Artemia salina
larvae as test organisms and LC 50 values as activity criteria). Furthermore, the authors partially characterized the antifouling bioactive components of their extracts and identified a mixture of fatty acids as the active fractions of both species of seagrasses.

Flavonoid 60 isolated from
E. acoroides
showed significant dose dependent anti-larval settlement activity against the larvae of the bryozoan
Bugula neritina
while 57 and sterols 151 and 153 showed only weak activity ( Qi et al., 2008 ).

paragraph.emphasis: 4.6. Antifeedant activity on insects and cytotoxicity towards insect cells

subSection.paragraph:
Qi et al. (2008) evaluated ssavonoids 47 , 57 , and 60 from
E. acoroides
in an anti-insect assay using larvae and cells of
Spodoptera litura
. Apigenin 47 showed significant effects while 57 and 60 were only moderately active. This study is also mentioned by Cabrita et al. (2010) in their review on halogenated compounds from marine algae.

Extracts of
H. ovalis
showed dose-dependent antioxidant activity (Yuvaraj et al., 2012). Extracts containing free and cell wall bound phenolic compounds of
P. oceanica
were evaluated for their antioxidant activity ( Kesraoui et al., 2011 ). Apart from dose dependent antioxidant activity, the authors observed that ssavonoids were about two thirds bound and only one third occurring as free ssavonoids, while about 44% of the total of phenolics occurred as free compounds. Not unexpectedly, phenolics with more than one free hydroxyl group isolated from
T. ciliatum
showed antioxidant activity in the DPPH assay ( Hamdy et al., 2012 ).

Extracts of
H. ovalis
showed dose-dependent anti-inssammatory activity in an assay using the inhibition of the proliferation of mitogen-induced peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) as a proxy (Yuvaraj et al., 2012).

heading.emphasis: 4.9. Inhibitory activity on mussel detoxification systems

subSection.paragraph:
Eufemia et al. (2002) included
P. scouleri
and
Z. marina
in their panel of ‘‘seaweeds” which they checked for inhibitory activity on the multixenobiotic resistance of
Mytilus californianus
mussels. The authors performed competition assays using the accumulation of the ssuorescent dye substrate rhodamine B within mussels as a proxy for the decreased ability of mussels to excrete potentially toxic compounds from their bodies using a p-glycoprotein like transporter. The authors reported inhibitory activity for extracts from
P. scouleri
but not for an extract obtained from
Z. marina
.

heading.emphasis: 4.10. Development of an herbal medicine from T. testudinum

subSubSection.paragraph:
Rodeiro et al. (2008a) demonstrated that
T. testudinum
extracts had only marginal cytotoxicity towards rat hepatocytes and did not significantly interfere with P450 enzymes. Moreover, Rodeiro et al. (2008b) demonstrated that
T. testudinum
extracts had moderate in vivo hepatoprotective effects versus several standard hepatotoxins. Rodeiro et al. (2009) later reported inhibition of CYP1A1/2 and 3A4 but not CYP2D6 activity by
T. testudinum
extracts and cautioned that this could potentially induce herbal-drug interactions when using
Thalassia
based medical products. This preliminary study was followed by a more detailed study ( Rodeiro et al., 2012 ) confirming previous results and adding additional detailed knowledge for more enzymes and also for the in vitro activity of the main metabolite thalassiolin B 71 .

Regalado et al. (2009) reported dose-dependent recovery of UVB damaged mouse skin when applying an aqueous ethanolic extract of
T. testudinum
. Regalado et al. (2011) while studying the apolar compounds of
T. testudinum
leaf extract also proved the ability of these apolar compounds to decrease visible and histological alteration of mouse skin irradiated with UV-B by attenuating the oxidative stress caused by UV-B radiation during the first hours after irradiation.

Based on these bioactivity studies, a standardized aqueous/ ethanol extract of
T. testudinum
leaves (BM-21) is being developed in Cuba as an herbal medicine ( Regalado et al., 2012 ). In this context, the antioxidant activity of BM-21 was evaluated ( Regalado et al., 2012 ). Moreover, anti-nociceptive activity of the extract and its main phenolic, 71 , was assessed and potency and concentration of 71 made it plausible that this compound accounted for most of the activity found for the extract ( Garateix et al., 2011 ). Menéndez et al. (2014) investigated neuroprotective and antioxidant effects of BM-21 using the acrylamide-induced mice neurotoxicity model. The authors reported significant and dose-dependent activity in orally administered extract and explain the activity of the extract with its anti-oxidative properties. Ansoar et al. (2014) using a
S. typhimurium
based experimental assay, found no hints for mutagenic or genotoxic actions of the standardized BM-21 extract. Also teratogenic and embryotoxic activities of BM-21 were ruled out based on experiments with Wistar rats ( de la Torre Núñez et al., 2014 ). The Cuban research efforts on
T. testudinum
and on the bioactivities of BM- 21 in particular were summarized by de la Torre Núñez et al. (2012) .

heading.emphasis: 5. Studies on the chemical ecology of seagrasses
5.1. Variations of seagrass metabolites in response to ecological factors

subSection.paragraph:
In an interesting study, Buchsbaum et al. (1990) observed an inverse correlation of total phenol and nitrogen content in
Z. marina
. Plants grown on a muddy substrate had higher nitrogen and lower phenolic contents compared to plants grown on a sandy substrate. Moreover, the authors observed that the plants higher in phenolics were resistant to wasting disease caused by members of the genus
Labyrinthula
while the plants with a low amount of phenolic compounds were not. Vergeer et al. (1995) demonstrated for
Z. marina
collected off the coast of Brittany , France that
Labyrinthula
infected leaves had higher contents of phenolics than uninfected leaves with the highest concentrations of phenolics in the immediate vicinity of
Labyrinthula
caused lesions. Moreover, the authors showed that higher light intensities were correlated with higher contents in phenolics; that lower temperatures were correlated with high phenolics contents; and that lower than ambient salinity was also correlated with slightly higher phenolic contents (Vergeer et al., 1995). Vergeer and Develi (1997) demonstrated that 16 , 25 , 28 , and 29 occurred in
Labyrinthula
infected
Z. marina
leaves collected off the coast of Brittany , France in higher quantities than in uninfected leaves. In their review assessing different biomarkers for early detection of stress in seagrasses, Ferrat et al. (2003) also mentioned the reaction of phenolic compound contents in seagrasses to stress factors such as infection with
Labyrinthula zosterae
, competition with other species (
Caulerpa racemosa
), and heavy metals. Though not covered here, because not referring to plant secondary metabolites; one focus of this review was the enumeration of seagrasses used as bio-indicators for metallic contamination of the environment and the particular metals studied in the summarized studies.

McKone and Tanner (2009) followed up hints that there might be a positive correlation between salinity and the extent of susceptibility of
Z. marina
populations to the wasting disease caused by
Labyrinthula
protists. The authors confirmed that the lesion area of artificially inoculated leaves was larger in plants grown in high salinity environments. Moreover, they demonstrated that ferulic acid 29 , gallic acid 16 , and rosmarinic acid 32 contents positively correlated with the size of the lesions.

paragraph.tableNote: Seagrasses, their organs, their symbionts and parasites, and some of the ecological factors which might influence their content in secondary metabolites. Legend: 1 Seagrass leaves, 2 seagrass rhizomes, 3 seagrass roots, 4 seagrass epibionts, 5 endophytic seagrass bacteria, 6 endophytic seagrass fungi, 7 substrate seagrasses are growing in, 8 seawater seagrasses are growing in, 9 predators feeding on seagrasses, 10 extra-marine environment with an impact on the life in the sea (temperature, compounds entering the sea via the air, 11 solar radiation, basis of life on land and in the sea but also stress factor (e.g. UV-B radiation).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 20. Seagrasses, their symbionts, parasites, predators, and environment.

subSection.paragraph:
Seagrasses of the genus
Thalassia
(
T. hemprichii
and
T. testudinum
) were also used to assess differences in feeding pressure between different habitats: reef-slope, reef-ssat, sand-plain, and lagoon ( Hay, 1984 ). The chemistry of the seagrasses was not the focus of this study but the ecology of herbivory in marine environments. In an interesting study, Hay et al. (1987) used palatable seagrass leaves of
T. testudinum
as substrate for feeding experiments to evaluate the antifeedant activity, against a species of sea urchin and different coral reef fish species, of compounds isolated from other marine organisms. Test compounds were applied as diethyl ether solutions to the surface of seagrass leaves and the experiments were performed after evaporation of the diethyl ether. Targett et al. (1986) showed that
T. testudinum
was the most preferred food of parrotfish (
Sparisoma radians
) when given the choice between
Halimeda
,
Penicillus
, and
Thalassia
. The authors could demonstrate that biteability was not the cause of the feeding preferences but the absence of 1,4-diacetoxy-1,3-butadiene terpenes, feeding deterrents present in both other genera investigated. In a related study Targett and Targett (1990) showed that
T. testudinum
was richer in nutrients than
Halimeda incrassata
and contained no feeding deterrents. However,
S. radians
was able to partially compensate this by higher alimentary tract evacuation rates when feeding on
Halimeda
. The authors also demonstrated that secondary metabolites from
Halimeda
when applied on
Thalassia
reduced consumption of
Thalassia
. However, the applied amounts neither altered digestive efficiency nor alimentary tract evacuation rates.

Paul et al. (1990) included two seagrasses
― E. acoroides
and
H. uninervis ―
in their study on chemical defences of tropical ‘‘seaweeds”. In the superficial phytochemical part of their study, the authors were not able to detect secondary metabolites in any of the two species and
E. acoroides
was eaten with low preference by adult and medium preference by juvenile fish while
H. uninervis
was eaten with medium preference by both adult and juvenile fish. Irelan and Horn (1991) demonstrated that coating of prepared food strips neither with polar nor with nonpolar extracts of
P. scouleri
affected the feeding behavior of the herbivorous fish species
Cebidichthys violaceus
.

Meyer et al. (1994) investigated the effects of seaweed and seagrass extracts and secondary metabolites on feeding behavior of the herbivorous surgeonfish
Naso lituratus
. The two seagrass species included in the study were
E. acoroides
and
H. uninervis
. The crude extract of
Enhalus acaroides
proved to be feeding deterrent. Extracts of
H. uninervis
were not tested but whole plants were assessed as ‘‘low preference”, indicating that these plants might also contain some feeding deterrents.

Without identifying the active compounds, Vergés et al. (2007a) proved that extracts of
P. oceanica
deterred feeding by the sea urchins
Arbacia lixula
,
Paracentrotus lividus
, and
Sphaerorechinus granularis
as well as by the general assemblage of fish species living in the region where the
Posidonia
samples were collected (off Port Lligat at the NE Spanish coast) but not feeding by the gastropod
Cerithium vulgatum
. In a related study, Vergés et al. (2007b) demonstrated that both the fish
Sarpa salpa
and the sea urchin
P. lividus
fed on reproductive and vegetative organs of
P. oceanica
to different degrees with inssorescences being the preferred food due to the lack of structural defences present in leaves. Moreover, the authors demonstrated that the softer vegetative tissues contained higher amounts of potentially feeding deterrent phenolics. In contrast to this antifeedant hypothesis of phenolics, the same authors could not detect any induction of phenolics by herbivory (Vergés et al., 2008). On the contrary, herbivory led to leaves containing lower levels of phenolics. This was interpreted by the authors as a reallocation of these compounds towards primary functions such as cell-wall construction.

Arnold et al. (2008) reported increasing proanthocyanidin concentrations in
T. testudinum
after simulated fish grazing, while no such response was observed after grazing by the sea urchin
Lychetinus variegatus
and after treatment with the hormone jasmonic acid. However, urchin grazing did induce tannin production in root/rhizome tissues. Condensed tannin accumulations were correlated with a reduction of blade extension rates. Interestingly, levels in developing first-rank leaves were strongly correlated with the width of second-rank leaves on each shoot, indicating that wider source leaves could provide additional resources for phenolic biosynthesis.

Tomas et al. (2011) examined how different genotypes of
Z. marina
were affected by extreme nitrogen loading and how genotypes differed in susceptibility to herbivorous isopod
Idotea resecata
. The authors concluded that chemical rather than structural differences among genotypes caused differences in palatability of
Z. marina
. Nitrogen addition uniformly decreased plant palatability but did not greatly alter the relative preferences of herbivores among genotypes. The authors only determined total phenols using the Folin and Ciocalteu method (1927) but did not identify any specific compound as feeding deterrent.

Steele and Valentine (2012) investigated the effect of grazing by the sea urchin
L. variegatus
on the concentrations of phenolics in
H. wrightii
and
T. testudinum
. Grazing impacts on phenolic acids and condensed tannins varied with season, urchin density, and distance from urchin damage. Phenolic concentrations were higher in both species in summer than in fall. Grazing led to increased condensed tannin concentrations in
T.testudinum
but had few effects on phenolic acid concentrations, p -hydroxybenzoic acid 10 concentrations increased locally in the grazed area and in areas> 2 cm above grazing. Similarly, condensed tannins in grazed
H. wrightii
leaves increased with urchin density in summer but decreased in fall while having few predictable effects on phenolic acid concentrations. Choice feeding experiments in which urchins were offered agar food made with high- and low-phenolic seagrass tissues, demonstrated high phenolic concentrations did not reduce urchin feeding, suggesting that the phenolics did not act as feeding protectants.

Buchsbaum and Valiela (1987) reported that Canada geese (
Brenta canadensis
) in Massachusetts heavily consume
Z. marina
in late spring and summer but less so in autumn. Moreover, these authors reported that goslings and breeding birds switch to
Zostera
(from other food sources such as
Spartina alterniflora
and
Spartina patens
and
Juncus gerardii
) later than non-breeding adult birds. The authors related these differences in feeding preferences to high contents in soluble carbohydrates in
Zostera
during summer but also to low contents of phenolics and the absence of tannins and other feeding deterrents.

Raniello et al. (2007) studied allelopathic effects of secondary metabolites of a competing organism (the invasive alga
C. racemosa
) on the seagrass
Cymodocea nodosa
. The authors demonstrated that the sesquiterpene caulerpenyne but not the co-occurring compounds caulerpin and caulerpicin had an inhibitory effect on the studied seagrass species.

Pergent et al. (2008) investigated how the competition between
P. oceanica
and the invasive alga
Caulerpa taxifolia
changed various parameters in both species. When in competition with
Posidonia
,
Caulerpa
had lower amounts of the sesquiterpene caulerpenyne and higher growth rates, while
Posidonia
had smaller leaves, a higher leaf-turnover and an unchanged level of phenolic compounds. These results were interpreted as investment in different competition strategies, growth rather than defence in
Caulerpa
and defence rather than growth in
Posidonia
. However, the authors have focused on a small part of the potentially bioactive compounds from both species and thus, also other interpretations might be valid.

heading.emphasis: 5.5. Seagrasses as a food source promoting biological invasions

subSection.paragraph:
Mollo et al. (2008) stated that the invasion of the Mediterranean Sea by the mollusc
S. geographica
was preceded by the invasion by its food source
H. stipulacea
. The authors assumed that
H. stipulacea
not only serves as a food source for the molluscs but that secondary metabolites from the seagrass are taken up by these animals and employed as chemical defence agents. The ecological success of these molluscs in their newly acquired geographic range is thus directly linked to the presence of the invasive seagrass species.

heading.emphasis: 5.6. Seasonal variation in seagrass secondary metabolites

subSection.paragraph:
Ravn et al. (1994) observed seasonal variation in phenolics (caffeic 28 and rosmarinic acid 32 ) in
Z. marina
leaves and rhizomes/roots collected in the Øresund region (between Denmark and Sweden and between the Baltic and North Seas). The authors observed a seasonal pattern with high contents in young leaves early in the season and significantly lower yields in older leaves later in the season. Moreover, the results disproved the authors’ hypotheses on roles of the quantified compounds as inhibitors of epiphytic colonization, an inssuence of herbivore grazing on their content or an inssuence of plant nutrient status on their biosynthesis. It should also be mentioned that the rather harsh drying conditions and the assumedly long delay between collection and analyses make it seem possible that the quantified compounds were not (entirely) genuine natural products but (partially) degradation products and/or artefacts. Also Rotini et al. (2013) reported on significantly higher concentrations of phenolics [quantified using the Folin and Ciocalteu method (1927) method] in rhizomes during summer (June) compared to winter (February). The authors moreover described a gradient of phenolics in rhizomes with the highest concentrations measured in the apical parts and the lowest in the basal parts of the rhizomes.

heading.emphasis: 5.7. Chemical reactions of seagrasses to microbial infections

subSection.paragraph:
Steele et al. (2005) studied the composition of
T. testudinum
leaves after infection with the protist
Labyrinthula
. These authors found no evidence for an increased production of phenolics but observed a hindered transport of simple phenolics 7 , 10 , 13 , and 25 caused by infection lesions. Therefore, concentrations of phenolics were higher above lesion sites but not higher below lesion sites. As this pattern could be confounded with induction, the authors termed this accumulation pattern of secondary metabolites ‘‘pseudo-induction”. The otherwise interesting study is ssawed by the poor phytochemical analytical systems which were used. In fact, the analyzed and quantified phenolics were most probably not genuine natural products but only products of hydrolysis of unknown genuine natural products.

Though unfortunately not directly studying the chemical composition of
Z. marina
after infection with the protist
L. zosterae , Brakel et al. (2014)
hypothesize based on up-regulation of genes involved in phenolics synthesis that contents of phenolic compounds will be upregulated after infection and that these compounds might play a crucial role in minimizing the negative effects for the seagrasses infected.

A total of 371 chemosystematic reports [chemosystematic report = compound reported for one taxon (Zidorn, 2008)] are available for seagrasses (Table S1). As also observed earlier for sesquiterpenoids from the Cichorieae tribe of the Asteraceae family (Zidorn, 2008), the predominant number of seagrass metabolites has been reported only from one source (Table S1). However, in contrast to the data from the Cichorieae , more than one compound has been reported for nearly all taxa and the mean number for reported compounds per taxon is 10.9, while the median is 7.5 (Table S1). These relatively high numbers are explainable by the relatively limited number of seagrass species, their extraordinary ecological significance, but mainly because of the existence of a number of comparative studies which cover only a limited number of secondary metabolites but secondary metabolites (phenolics and sterols), which are ubiquitous in the studied taxa.

A question not easily answered based on the available data but also because suitable data for valid comparisons are hardly available is the question whether the chemical diversity found in seagrasses is high or low compared to ‘‘normal” higher plants, i.e. higher plants living on land or in freshwater habitats. Given the fact that seagrasses are exposed to a number of unique challenges ( Fig. 20 ) such as predation from a whole range of animal phyla not living on land as well as stress factors related to their marine (saline) and submersed (limited supply of oxygen) life style ( Borum et al., 2006 ), a high diversity of defence chemicals might be expected and is partially also documented for some of the better studied species such as
Cymodocea nodosa
,
H. stipulacea
, and
P. oceanica
. On the other hand the opposite could be assumed, i.e. a relatively low number of secondary metabolites in seagrasses, because seagrasses are phylogenetically closely related taxa belonging to few closely related families ( Bremer et al., 2009 ). Thus, many compound classes which are restricted to certain phylogenetic clades, e.g. irdioids, polyacetylenes, and sesquiterpene lactones, are not expected to occur in seagrasses (and have in fact not been found yet).

The bioactivities so far reported for seagrass metabolites include frequently studied activities of potential interest for the development of human medicines such as cytotoxicity, antimicrobial activity, antiviral activity, and anti-inssammatory activity. Moreover, bioactivities of interest for the plants producing the secondary metabolites were assayed such as phytotoxicity, antimacrofouling activity, antifeedant activity, and inhibitory activity on mussel detoxification systems. The reported activities in the fields interesting for an application in humans are not exceptional. On the other hand, the activities of interest for the ecology of the seagrasses producing them are very hard to compare because such studies have rarely been performed and values from other compounds and extracts are therefore rare.

The seasonal variation of phenolics observed by Ravn et al. (1994) in
Z. marina
leaves is similar to the pattern observed for phenolics in leaves of the submediterranean shrub
Celtis australis ( Sommavilla et al., 2012 )
. Interestingly, the increase of phenolic levels at lower temperatures as described for
Z. marina
by Vergeer et al. (1995) is paralleled by results found for higher plants growing on land ( Albert et al., 2009 ).

Some interesting aspects of seagrasses and their secondary metabolites fields of research have not been sufficiently addressed or have not been re-examined with the latest available analytical techniques. These aspects include:

1. For species with large areas of distribution such as the Northern temperate
Z. marina ( Mabberley, 2008 )
samples should be taken from as many different geographic regions as possible to determine geographical variation with regards to phytochemistry. These analyses should ideally be accompanied by molecular phylogenetic studies. With such studies not only the geographical phytochemical variation of secondary metabolites from seagrasses can be studied but also hitherto undetected cryptic species of seagrasses could both be detected and phenetically characterized.

2. More lab work will be required for the isolation and structure elucidation of currently still unknown secondary metabolites such as the genuine ssavonoid glycosides of
P. oceanica
and the sulfated caffeoyl quinic acid derivatives reported from various genera decades ago ( Harborne and Williams, 1976 ) but still only partially characterized.

3. Finally, detailed studies on the ecological factors inssuencing the spectrum and concentration of secondary seagrass metabolites seem to be warranted, and in particular for ecologically important seagrasses such as
P. oceanica
in the Mediterranean and
Z. marina
in the seas of the Northern hemisphere. Factors with a potential impact on secondary metabolites could encompass the following: Ontogenetic factors, seasonal factors, grazing, sea depth (causing gradients in temperature and radiation), temperature gradients, salinity gradients, and competition by other organisms.

May 2015

subSection.paragraph: Christian Zidorn studied Pharmacy at the University of Düsseldorf/ Germany and became a registered pharma- cist in 1995. From 1995 to 1998 he pursued PhD studies in Pharmacognosy in the group of Prof. Hermann Stup- pner at the University of Innsbruck/ Austria . After receiving his Dr. rer. nat. degree in 1998, he did post- doctoral research in the Plant Extracts Research Unit of Crop & Food in Dunedin/ New Zealand from 2000 to 2001 under the supervision of Nigel B . Perry. After returning to Innsbruck, he completed habilitations (state doctorates) in Pharmacognosy (2003) and Botany (2007). From 2010 to 2013, he worked in the group of Dr. Anna Lönnroth in Brussels / Belgium as a scientific research officer in the field of infectious diseases with the European Commission; here he was mainly responsible for FP7 collaborative projects in the fields of antimicrobial resistance and emerging epidemics. After again working as an associate professor at the University of Innsbruck and a step-in professorship at the University of Kiel/ Germany , he is currently studying marine natural compounds as a Marie Curie IEF grant holder at the CNR ― Istituto di Chimica Biomolecolare in Pozzuoli/ Italy in the group of Margherita Gavagnin. From April 2016 on, Dr. Zidorn will be leading the Department of Pharmaceutical Biology of the Institute of Pharmacy at the University of Kiel/ Germany . His research interests include phytochemistry, chemosystematics, botanical systematics, and chemical ecology. He has published more than 100 papers in national and international journals, discovered some dozens of new natural compounds from various compound classes such as sesquiterpenoids, diterpenes, phenolic acids, iridoids, and polyacetylenes and serves as a regular referee for e.g. Biochemical Systematics and Ecology, Phytochemistry, and Planta Medica. His current research focuses on chemosystematics of the Cichorieae ( Asteraceae ), on bio-actives from vegetables, on altitudinal variation of secondary metabolites, and on marine natural products, their bioactivities and ecological functions.
